item.title: Index
item.description: Here is my second brain, enjoy. Some quick links: General Overview of GLM & GLzM
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Culture
item.description: Shared patterns of behavior and experience derived from settings in which people live. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019) A system or web of sharing meaning, shared understanding, and shared sense making.
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Cultural Competence
item.description: Familiarity with and, more important, sensitivity to other peoples' ways of doing things. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019) The awareness, knowledge, and skills needed to function effectively with culturally diverse populations.
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Unconscious
item.description: Memories, feelings, and impulses of which an individual is unaware. Often used as a noun, but more appropriately limited to use as an adjective. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Triadic Model
item.description: Explanations based on the interactions among three people or objects; Johnny shoplifts because his father covertly encourages him to defy his mother. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Transference
item.description: Distorted emotional reactions to present relationships based on unresolved, early family relations. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Three-Generational Hypothesis of Schizophrenia
item.description: Bowen's concept that schizophrenia is the end result of low levels of differentiation passed on and amplified across three succeeding generations. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Therapist Variables
item.description: Attributes of the therapist that are thought to contribute to successful outcomes, such as the ability to flexibly adapt their approach to the needs of the clients. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Therapeutic Alliance
item.description: The relationship between the therapist and clients. The therapeutic alliance is thought to consist of tasks, bonds, and goals. It is the common factor that enjoys the most empirical support. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: System
item.description: A group of interrelated elements plus the way they function together. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Symmetrical Relationship
item.description: In relationships, equality or parallel form. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Social Learning Theory
item.description: Understanding and treating behavior using principles from social and developmental psychology as well as from learning theory. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Social Exchange Theory
item.description: Thibaut and Kelley's theory according to which people strive to maximize rewards and minimize costs in a relationship. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Separation-Individuation
item.description: Process whereby the infant begins, at about two months, to draw apart from the symbiotic bond with mother and develop his or her autonomous functioning. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Selfobject
item.description: Kohut's term for an individual related to not as a separate individual but as an extension of the self (rather than relating to that person as sex or aggression). (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Self Psychology
item.description: Heinz Kohut's version of psychoanalysis that emphasizes the need for attachment and appreciation. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Second-Order Cybernetics (1960s-1980s)
item.description: The idea that anyone attempting to observe and change a system is therefore part of that system. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Schizophrenogenic Mother
item.description:
Frieda Fromm-Reichmann (1948)'s term for aggressive, domineering mothers thought to precipitate schizophrenia in their offspring. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
Frieda Fromm-Reichmann (1948)
Schizophrenia
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Scapegoat
item.description: A member of the family, usually the Identified Patient (IP), who is the object of displaced conflict or criticism. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Runaway
item.description: Unchecked positive feedback that causes a family or system to get out of control. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Rubber Fence
item.description: Lyman Wynne (1954) 1 term for the rigid boundary surrounding many schizophrenic families, which allows only minimal contact with the surrounding community. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Role-Play
item.description: Acting out the parts of important characters to dramatize feelings and practice new ways of relating. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Role Rehearsal
item.description: Role-Play desired ways of behaving, especially in couples therapy. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Rituals
item.description: In Strategic Family Therapy, a set of prescribed actions designed to change a family system's rules. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Restraining
item.description: A Strategic Family Therapy technique for overcoming Resistance by suggesting that a family not change. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Resistance
item.description: Anything that patients or families do to oppose or retard the progress of therapy. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Regression
item.description: Return to a less-mature level of functioning in the face of stress. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Reframing
item.description: Relabeling a family's description of behavior to make it more amenable to therapeutic change; for example, describing someone as 'lazy' rather than 'depressed.' (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Reflecting Team
item.description: Tom Anderson's technique of having the observing team share their reactions with the family following a session. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Randomized Controlled Trial
item.description: A research design in which carefully screened participants are randomly assigned to one of two or more bona-fide treatments or a control group, treatments are administered in a carefully controlled manner, and results are compared to determine the most effective treatment. Commonly used in medicine and historically in mental health research, although its popularity in the latter is fading. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Quid Pro Quo
item.description: Literally, 'something for something,' an equal exchange or substitution. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019) Lederer & Jackson proposed The Quid Pro Quo contract as an implicit contract that every relationship contains. It is a contract in which people exchange positive things with one another. They suggested this kind of reciprocity breaks down in relationships that are ailing, and trust becomes eroded. In 1977 Bernard Murstein found that quid-pro-quo way of thinking was characteristic of both ailing friendships and relationships. Once a partner becomes an emotional 'accountant' there is something wrong. (i.e., when the thinking is, "I did this for that person and it never got reciprocated,"), then that is a sign that the relationship is in trouble.
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Psychoeducational Family Therapy
item.description: A type of therapy developed in work with schizophrenics, which emphasizes educating family members to help them understand and cope with a seriously disturbed family member. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Pseudomutuality
item.description: Lyman Wynne (1954) 1's term for the fa√ßade of family harmony that characterizes many schizophrenic families. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Pseudohostility
item.description:
Wynne's term for superficial bickering that masks pathological alignments in schizophrenic families. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
Lyman Wynne (1954) 1
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Projective Identification
item.description: A defense mechanism that operates unconsciously, whereby unwanted aspects of the self are attributed to another individual, and that individual is induced to behave in accordance with these projected attitudes and feelings. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Process
item.description:
How members of a family or group relate. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
A continuous series of actions or changes that rsult in a given set of circumstances or phenomena. (@kerrFamilyEvaluation1988)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Process Research
item.description: Quantitative or qualitative research that systematically observes treatment delivery to determine processes indicative of successful therapy. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Pretend Techniques
item.description: Madanes's playful paradoxical intervention in which family members are asked to pretend to engage in symptomatic behavior. The paradox is if they are pretending to have a symptom, the symptom cannot be real. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Prescribing the Symptom
item.description: A paradoxical technique that forces a patient to either give up a symptom or admit that it is under voluntary control. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Preferred View
item.description: Eron and Lund's term for the way people would like to think of themselves and be seen by others. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Postmodernism
item.description:
Contemporary antipositivism, viewing knowledge as relative and context-dependent; questions assumptions of objectivity that characterize modern science. In family therapy, challenging the idea of scientific certainty and linked to the method of deconstruction. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
Narrative Therapy
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Positive Feedback
item.description:
Information that confirms and reinforces the direction a system is taking. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
Feedback Loop
Cybernetics
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Positive Connotation
item.description: Selvini Palazzoli's technique of ascribing positive motives to family behavior in order to promote family cohesion and avoid resistance to therapy. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Parental Child
item.description: A child who has been allocated power to take care of younger siblings; adaptive when done deliberately in large or single-parent families, maladaptive when it results from unplanned abdication of parental responsibility. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Paradoxical Injunction
item.description: A technique used in Strategic Family Therapy whereby the therapist directs family members to continue their symptomatic behavior. If they conform, they admit control and expose secondary gain; if they rebel, they give up their symptoms. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019) Not to point out that an individual is fighting going under, but instead tell the individual to keep their eyes open until they become unbearably heavy.
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Paradox
item.description: A self-contradictory statement based on a valid deduction from acceptable premises. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Overgeneralization
item.description:
Isolated incidents are taken as general patterns. Example: After being turned down for a date, a young man decides that 'Women don't like me; I'll never get a date.' Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019
Cognitive Distortions
Cognitive-Behavioral Therapy (CBT)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Ordeals
item.description: A type of paradoxical intervention in which the client is directed to do something that is more of a hardship than the symptom. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Open System
item.description: A set of interrelated elements that exchange information, energy, and material with the surrounding environment. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Object Relations
item.description:
Internalized images of self and others based on early parent-child interactions that determine an individual's mode of relationship to other people. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
University Resources/Couple and Family Therapy/People in CFT/Henry Dicks
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Object Relations Theory
item.description: Psychoanalytic theory derived from Melanie Klein and developed by the British School (Bion, Fairbairn, Guntrip, Winnicott) that emphasizes relationships and attachment, rather than libidinal and aggressive drives, as the key issues of human concern. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Nuclear Family
item.description: Parents and their children. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Neutrality
item.description: Selvini Palazzoli's term for balanced acceptance of family members. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Negative Feedback
item.description:
Information that signals a system to correct a deviation and restore the status quo. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
Feedback Loop
Cybernetics
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Narcissism
item.description: Self-regard. Exaggerated self-regard most people equate with narcissisms is pathological narcissism. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Mystification
item.description: Laing's concept that many families distort their children's experience by denying it or relabeling it. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Mystery Questions
item.description: Questions designed to get clients wondering how their problems got the best of them, which helps to externalize the problems. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Morphogenesis
item.description: The process by which a system changes its structure to adapt to new contexts. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019) As the system assesses information from internal and external interactions it may 'choose' to change in order to accommodate to the new information.
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Modeling
item.description: Observational Learning (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Mirroring
item.description: Expression of understanding and acceptance of another's feelings. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Metacommunication
item.description:
Every message has two levels: report and command; metacommunication is the implied command or qualifying message. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
Gregory Bateson
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Meta-Analysis
item.description: A research methodology that quantitatively aggregates the findings of multiple studies focused on a common phenomenon. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Marital Skew
item.description:
Lidz's term for a pathological marriage in which one spouse dominates the other. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
Marital Schism
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Marital Schism
item.description:
Lidz's term for pathological overt marital conflict. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
Marital Skew
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Managed Care
item.description: A system in which third-party companies manage insurance costs by regulating the terms of treatment. Managed care companies select providers, set fees, and control who receives treatment and how many sessions they are entitled to. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Linear Causality
item.description: The idea that one event is the cause and another is the effect; in behavior, the idea that one behavior is a stimulus, the other a response. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Invisible Loyalties
item.description: Ivan Boszormenyi-Nagy's term for unconscious and commitments that children take on to help their families. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Invariant Prescription
item.description: A technique developed by Mara Selvini Palazzoli in which parents are directed to mysteriously sneak away together. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Introjection
item.description: A primitive form of identification; taking in aspects of other individuals, which then become part of the self-image. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Internal Validity
item.description: The degree to which a study measures what it claims to measure. Internal validity is achieved by controlling the effects of as many variable that might affect the outcome of the study as possible. Studies with high internal validity tend to have low external validity since nobody delivers services in such a tightly controlled manner to such carefully screened clients. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Internal Objects
item.description: Mental images and fantasies of oneself and others, formed by early interactions with caregivers. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Internal Family Systems Model
item.description: A model of the mind that uses systemic principles and techniques understand and change intrapsychic processes, developed by Richard Schwartz. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Instrumental Leader
item.description: Decision-making and task functions; in traditional families, the husband's role. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Identified Patient (IP)
item.description: The symptom-bearer or official patient as identified by the family. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Identification
item.description: From psychoanalytic theory, not merely imitation but appropriation of traits of an admired other. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Idealization
item.description: A tendency to exaggerate the virtues of someone, part of the normal developmental process in children's relationships to their parents and in intimate partnerships. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Hope and Expectancy Factors
item.description: The hope a therapist and client have in the successful outcome of therapy; thought to increase the chances of successful therapy. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Group Dynamics
item.description: Interactions among group members that emerge as a result of properties of the group rather than merely their individual personalities. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Genogram
item.description:
A schematic diagram of the family system, using squares to represent men, circles to indicate women, horizontal lines for marriages, and vertical lines to indicate children. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
A multigenerational family tree that symbolically represents different dynamics related to family and individual functioning that is psychologic, cultural, and interpersonal in nature. (@russoDSM5FamilySystems2024) ‚ÄúGenogram Symbols.pdf‚Äù could not be found.
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Generalizability
item.description: In learning theory terms, spreading effect. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Function of the System
item.description: The idea that the symptoms are often ways to distract or otherwise protect family members from threatening conflicts. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Fixation
item.description: Partial arrest of attachment or mode of behavior from an early stage of development. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: First-Order Cybernetics (1940s-1960s)
item.description: The idea that an outside observer can study and make changes in a system while remaining separate and independent of that system. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Family of Origin
item.description: An individual's parents and siblings; usually refers to the original nuclear family of an adult. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Family System
item.description: The family conceives as a collective whole entity made up of individual parts plus the way they function together. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Family Ritual
item.description: Technique used by Selvini Palazzoli and her Milan associates that prescribes a specific act for family members to perform, which is designed to change the family system's rules. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Family Projection Process
item.description: In Bowenian theory, the mechanism by which parental conflicts are projected onto the children or a spouse. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Family Myths
item.description: A set of beliefs based on a distortion of historical reality and shared by all family members that help shape the rules governing family functioning. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Family Life Cycle
item.description: Stages of family life from separation from parents to marriage, having child, growing older, retirement, and finally death. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Family Homeostasis
item.description: Tendency of families to resist change in order to maintain a steady state. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Family Group Therapy
item.description: Family treatment based on the group therapy model. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Family Drawing
item.description: An experiential therapy technique in which family members are asked to draw their ideas about how the family is organized. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Extratherapeutic Factors
item.description: Factors in a client's life that are outside of the scope of therapy but have a strong bearing on the client's life, such as jobs, neighborhood, or family composition. Changes in extratherapeutic factors have been hypothesized to account for more change than what occurs in therapy. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Extinction
item.description: Eliminating behavior by not reinforcing it. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Externalization
item.description:
Michael White's technique of personifying problems as external to individuals. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
Social Constructionism
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: External Validity
item.description: The degree to which the results of a study are generalizable to populations outside a study; achieved by allowing the study conditions to approximate standard practice as much as possible. Studies with high external validity typically have low internal validity due to the lack of control present in treatment delivery and clinical sample. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Extended Family
item.description: The network of kin relationships across several generations. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Exception
item.description:
De Shazer's term for times when clients are temporarily free of their problems. Solution-focused therapists focus on exceptions to help clients build on successful problem-solving skills. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
Steve de Shazer
Solution-Focused Therapy
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Ethnicity
item.description: The common ancestry through which groups of people have evolved shared values and customs. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Equifinality
item.description: The ability of complex systems to reach a given final goal in a variety of different ways. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Epistemology
item.description: The branch of philosophy concerned with the study of knowledge. Used by Gregory Bateson to mean worldview or belief system. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019) Way of knowing
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Entitlement
item.description: Ivan Boszormenyi-Nagy's term for the amount of merit a person accrues for behaving in an ethical manner toward others. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Empirically Validated Treatment
item.description: A treatment for which a substantial amount of research exists supporting its effectiveness. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Dyadic Model
item.description: Explanations based on the interactions between two individuals or objects; Johnny shoplifts to get his mother's attention. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Double Bind
item.description:
A conflict created when an individual receives contradictory messages on different levels of abstraction in an important relationship and cannot leave or comment. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
Gregory Bateson
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Directives
item.description: Homework assignments designed to help families interrupt homeostatic patterns of problem-maintaining behavior. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Detriangulation
item.description: The process by which individuals remove themselves from the emotional field of two others. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Cybernetics
item.description:
The science of feedback; how information, especially positive and negative feedback loops, can help self-regulate a system. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
Introduced by Gregory Bateson The study of feedback mechanisms in self-regulating systems
Feedback Loop: How a system gets information necessary to maintain a steady state. Can be positive or negative.
Negative Feedback: Indicates that a system is straying off the mark and that corrections are needed to get back on track. Room Temperature->Thermostat->Furnace->Room Temperature
Positive Feedback: Reinforces the direction a system is taking. Being out of Breath-> Overcorrecting-> Escalation of Panic attack->Being out of Breath If you see behavior persist over time, there is likely something maintaining that behavior. Cybernetics in Families: Sequences of family interaction around a problem; characterize system's reaction to it. What happens when the system's negative feedback is ineffective? Triggering positive feedback loops. Implications for MFTs: Oriented-Therapists strive for:
Second-Order Change Distinguishing it from first-order change Change in family rules
First-Order Change: Family changes behavior, but is still governed by the same rules.
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Cross-Generational Coalition
item.description: An inappropriate alliance between a parent and child, who side together against a third member of the family. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Countertransference

item.title: Testing Linearity
item.description:
The relationship between the Dependent Variable and each Independent Variable is linear. How to Check Use scatterplots to visualize relationships. Click Graphs > Legacy Dialogs > Scatter/Dot. Click Simple Scatter. Click Define.
Move your Dependent Variable (Outcome) to the Y-Axis. Move your Independent Variable (Predictor) to the X-Axis If the scatterplot is approximately linear, the assumption is met.
Example Plot house price against square footage to see if the relationship linear. Solution If not linear, apply transformations (e.g., log, square root)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Moderation
item.description:
Moderation occurs when the strength or direction of the relationship between an Independent Variable and a Dependent Variable changes depending on the level of a third variable, known as a Moderator. In other words, the moderator influences how, or under what conditions, the IV affects the DV. Helps determine under what conditions or for whom an effect holds true. Imagine you are studying the impact of a training program (IV) on job performance (DV). However, you hypothesize that this relationship differs based on work experience (moderator). For individuals with high work experience, the training might have a stronger (or weaker) effect on performance compared to those with low work experience. In this case, work experience moderates the effect of training on job performance.
When conducting moderation analysis (typically through Multiple Regression with an interaction term). Several assumptions should be met:
The relationship between predictors (including the interaction term) and the DV should be linear. Click Graphs > Legacy Dialogs > Scatter/Dot Choose 'Simple Scatter' and click Define
Plot the DV on the Y-axis and each predictor (and, if possible, the interaction term) on the X-axis. Look for a straight-line relationship between each predictor and the DV.
Run your Regression Analysis Analyze > Regression > Linear In the Linear Regression dialog, click Plots. Move the standardized predicted values on the X box and standardized residuals to the Y box. Click Continue and then OK. Check the plot for a random scatter (no obvious patterns or curves) which supports the linearity assumption. The variance of residuals should be consistent across levels of the predictors. Use the same plot created for checking linearity. Look for a consistent spread of residuals across all predicted values (no funnel shape or systematic change in spread). You can also use tests like the Breusch-Pagan test in SPSS (via additional syntax or plugins) if a more formal assessment is needed. Residuals from the regression should be approximately normally distributed. After running your regression, save the standardized residuals. Go to Graphs > Legacy Dialogs > Histogram and plot the residuals. The histogram should show a bell-shaped curve. In the regression dialog (Analyze > Regression > Linear), Click Plots. Add a Normal Q-Q plot by moving the standardized residuals to the Y box. A Q-Q plot where the points closely follow the diagonal line indicates that the residuals are normally distributed.
The observations should be independent of each other (i.e., no Autocorrelation) Ensure that your data collection method supports the assumption of independence (e.g., participants are sampled independently) When running the regression (Analyze > Regression > Linear), SPSS outputs the Durbin-Watson statistic. A value around 2 suggests that the residuals are independent. Values deviating substantially from 2 indicate potential issues. Predictor variables (including the interaction term) should not be too highly correlated.
Ensure that variables are centered (or standardized) to reduce Multicollinearity when creating interaction terms.
Multiply the centered IV and Moderator. Click Analyze > Regression > PROCESS v
Enter the IV, moderator, and the interaction term as Predictor s. For moderation analysis, use Model 1. PROCESS automatically creates the interaction term (Training x Work Experience) If your variables are continuous, it is often recommended to center them first (or use PROCESS options that center them automatically) IV and Moderator Coefficients: These represent the effect of the IV and moderator on the DV when the other variable is at its mean (if centered). Interaction Coefficient (IV √ó Moderator): Significance: A statistically significant interaction term (typically p < .05) indicates that the effect of the IV on the DV changes depending on the level of the moderator. Interpretation: If the coefficient is positive, as the moderator increases, the effect of the IV on the DV becomes stronger (or more positive); if negative, the effect weakens (or becomes more negative). Purpose: To determine how the IV-DV relationship varies at specific values of the moderator (e.g., at the mean, one standard deviation above, and one standard deviation below the mean). Output: SPSS (via PROCESS) often provides these slopes along with their confidence intervals and p-values. Suppose you get the following (hypothetical) output: IV (Training): b = 0.30, SE = 0.10, p = .003 Moderator (Work Experience): b = 0.20, SE = 0.08, p =.012 Interaction (Training √ó Work Experience): b = 0.15, SE = 0.05, p = .002 The significant interaction (p = .002) suggests that the effect of training on job performance depends on work experience. A simple slopes analysis might reveal that for individuals with high work experience (e.g., +1 SD), the effect of training on performance is stronger (say, b=0.45b = 0.45b=0.45) compared to those with low work experience (e.g., -1 SD, b=0.15b = 0.15b=0.15). Below is an example of how you might report your findings in APA style: A moderation analysis was conducted using the PROCESS macro (Model 1) to examine whether work experience moderated the relationship between training and job performance. The results indicated a significant interaction between training and work experience, b = 0.15, SE = 0.05, p = .002, suggesting that the effect of training on job performance varied as a function of work experience. Simple slopes analysis revealed that the relationship between training and job performance was stronger for participants with high work experience (b = 0.45, p < .001) compared to those with low work experience (b = 0.15, p = .045). These findings indicate that work experience significantly moderates the relationship between training and job performance.

item.title: MANOVA (Multivariate Analysis of Variance)
item.description:
Tests for differences in multiple DV s simultaneously across groups. Comparing groups on both exam scores and project grades. Analyze > General Linear Model > Multivariate
Move multiple DV s (e.g., exam scores, project grades) to the Dependent Variables box. Place the group variable in the Fixed Factor(s) box. Click OK. Interpretation: A p-value near 0.045 indicates caution. If p-value were below 0.001, the assumption would be clearly violated. When near threshold, consider robust multivariate tests (e.g., Pillai's Trace).
Interpretation: Both tests show significance (p = 0.003), indicating a multivariate effect of group on the combined DV s. A MANOVA was performed to assess group differences on exam scores and project grades. The multivariate tests indicated a significant effect of group, Wilks‚Äô Œõ = .73, F(4,114) = 4.21, p = .003. Follow-up univariate ANOVAs revealed significant differences for exam scores (F(2,57) = ‚Ä¶, p = ‚Ä¶) and project grades (F(2,57) = ‚Ä¶, p = ‚Ä¶). Box‚Äôs M test was marginal, M = 12.45, p = .045, warranting cautious interpretation.

item.title: Independent Samples T-Test
item.description:
The independent samples t-test is used to compare the means of two independent groups to determine whether there is a significant difference between them.
It is appropriate when you have one Categorical Independent Variable with two groups (e.g., male vs. Female) and one Continuous Dependent Variable (e.g., test scores). The Null Hypothesis assumes that there is no difference between the group means. Each observation in one group must be independent of observations in the other group. Participants should not belong to both groups. There should be no pairing between observations. Measurements should not be influenced by external factors. There is no direct statistical test for independence in SPSS. Ensure the study design guarantees independence (e.g., random assignment or naturally occurring groups like male/female).
The dependent variable should be approximately normally distributed within each group. The t-test is fairly robust to violations of normality if sample sizes are equal and large (e.g., n ‚â• 30 per group), but severe Skewness or Outliers can affect results. Click Analyze > Descriptive Statistics > Explore
Move your Dependent Variable to the 'Dependent List'.
Move your Independent Variable to 'Factor List'. Click Plots, check Normality Plots with Tests, and click Continue. Click OK.
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Independence of Observations
item.description: Each observation in one group must be independent of observations in the other group. Participants should not belong to both groups. There should be no pairing between observations. Measurements should not be influenced by external factors.
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Covariate
item.description: A covariate is an Independent Variable that is not the primary focus of your research but is included in the analysis because it might influence the Dependent Variable. In other words, it is a variable that you control for to help isolate the effect of your main Independent Variable(s). Covariates are used to adjust for variables that might confound the relationship between your main predictors and the outcome. For example, if you're studying the effect of a new teaching method on exam scores, you might include prior GPA as a covariate to account for baseline academic ability. By accounting for variability in the dependent variable that is due to covariates, you can reduce the error variance. This improves the precision of your estimates and increases the statistical power of your tests. Including covariates can help provide a clearer picture of the relationship between your primary variables of interest and the outcome, leading to more accurate and interpretable results. In analyses like ANCOVA (Analysis of Covariance), covariates are used to adjust the means of the groups so that comparisons are made at a common level of the covariate. Imagine you're evaluating the effectiveness of a training program (the primary independent variable) on job performance (the dependent variable). However, work experience (the covariate) might also affect job performance. By including work experience as a covariate, you control for its effect, allowing you to more accurately determine the impact of the training program on job performance.

item.title: Testing for Normality
item.description:
An assessment of the normality of data is a prerequisite for many statistical tests because normal data is an underlying assumption in parametric testing. SPSS allows you to test all of these procedures within Explore command. The Explore command can be used in isolation if you are testing normality in one group or splitting your dataset into one or more groups. If you have 2 or more categorical, independent variables, the Explore command on its own is not enough and you will have to use the Split File command also. Click Analyze -> Descriptives -> Explore Transfer the variable that needs to be tested for normality into the Dependent List box. Click on Statistics. Leave Descriptives selected. Click the Plots. Select Factor Levels Together under Boxplots. Select Stem-and-Leaf under Descriptive. Select Normality Plots with Tests. When testing for normality, we are mainly interested in the Tests of Normality table and the Normal Q-Q Plots, our numerical and graphical methods to test for the normality of data, respectively.
The above table presents the results from two well-known tests of normality, namely the Kolmogorov-Smirnov Test and the Shapiro-Wilk. The Shapiro-Wilk Test is more appropriate for small sample sizes (<50 samples), but can also handle sample sizes as large as 2000. If the Sig. value of the Shapiro-Wilk Test is greater than p = .05, the data is normal. If it is below 0.05, the data significantly deviate from a normal distribution.
In order to determine normality graphically, we can use the output of a normal P-P plot. If the data are normally distributed, the data points will be close to the diagonal line. If the data points stray from the line in an obvious non-linear fashion, the data are not normally distributed. If the points are generally along the diagonal, the assumption is met. If you are at all unsure of being able to correctly interpret the graph, rely on the numeric methods instead because it can take a fair bit of experience to correctly judge the normality of data based on plots.
If the histogram is approximately normal, the assumption is met. The distribution curve is normal/bell shaped. The assumption is met if the skewness and kurtosis is between +2 and -2. The Explore command on its own cannot separate the dependent variable into groups based on not one but two or more independent variables. However, we can perform this feat by using the Split File command. Click Data -> Split File Click Organize Output by Groups. Transfer the independent variables you wish to categorize the dependent variable on into the Groups Based On box. Proceed as above.

item.title: Simple Linear Regression (SLR)
item.description:
Also known as Ordinary Least Squares (OLS) Correlation does not imply causation. With proper literature review and research design, however we can investigate how one variable (x or IV) explains the variability (variance) in the other variable (y or DV). If x is indeed a significant predictor of y, we can use x to predict y. Still a bivariate analysis, but with a different goal in mind. For example, the school district might want to use GPA to explain the variable in ACT scores and use GPA to predict ACT.
Here we have only one predictor (IV) in the model: Simple Linear Regression (SLR). Regression means you are trying to find a pattern between x and y. You are using x to predict y. We are only using one.
If we square the Pearson correlation coefficient (r) between x and y, r2 indicates the proportion of the Variance in y that can be explained by x. HS GPA and ACT example: r = .698 Square it: r2 = (. 698)2 ‚âà .487 This indicates 48.7% of the variance in ACT scores can be explained (or accounted for) by GPA. Recall r ranges from -1 to 1. What does it mean for the range of r2? Recall 'ballpark' effect size: Weak (|r| ‚â• .2) Weak (r2 ‚â• .04 or 4%) Moderate (|r| ‚â• .4) Moderate (r2 ‚â• .16 or 16%) Strong (|r| ‚â• .8) Strong (r2 ‚â• .64 or 64%) ACES (Adverse Childhood Experiences) -> Psychological symptoms Word exposure frequency and elaboration of word processing in incidental vocab learning -> incidental vocabulary acquisition and retention through extensive reading The user's tech literacy or tech-savviness, overall product quality (design, build, execution, etc.), and many more -> User experience or user satisfaction of an EdTech product Student's participation -> Student's sense of belonging Grade point average -> Success in first year of college xi: IV data point for subject i yi: DV data point for subject i yi: Expected/predicted value for subject i (i.e., the regression line)
ùõΩ0: Intercept (Constant) ùõΩ1: Slope (How much DV increases as IV increases by 1 unit) One statistician movie fan decided to use statistics to study the movie ratings in his favorite movie guide, Movie and Video Guide (1996), by Leonard Maltin. Maltin rates movies on a one-star to four-star system, in increments of half-stars, with higher numbers being better. The guide also includes additional information on each film. The statistician used a random number generator to select a simple random sample of 100 movies rated by the Guide. Rating: Maltin rating (range is 1 to 4, in steps of 0.5) Length: Running time (in minutes) Year: Year the movie was released Cast: Number of case members listed in the guide Origin: Country (0 = USA, 1 = International) Finding b0 and b1 (regression coefficients) for the regression line:
Best estimates for b's are the ones that provide minimal error over any other collection of b's. Working with the squared values, our goal is to find estimate b0 and b1 to minimize the error sum of squares: SSE = The optimal solution: b0 = y-hat - b1x-bar Regression line goes through both means of x and y! The slope is determined by the correlation between x and y with a scale of y per change in x. Analyze -> Regression -> Linear
Drag Outcome variable into the 'Dependent' box
Drag the Predictor variable into the 'Block 1 of 1' box In the Statistics menu, select Estimates, Confidence Intervals, Model Fit, and Descriptive.
The default SPSS output has 3 sections: Model Summary (How much variance in DV is explained by the model) ANOVA Table (Model significance) Regression Coefficients (Equation for the regression line) Total variability (variance) in DV is partitioned into two parts: What we can explain by the model (regression) What we still cannot explain (error) Regression sum of squares (SSR) Error Sum of Squares (SSE) Total Sum of Squares (SSTO) SSTO = SSR + SSE SSR, SSE, and SSTO are available in the ANOVA table R2 indicates the proportion of variance in DV explained (accounted for) by the model, which can be considered the overall model fit. R2 = (SSR) √∑ (SSTO) = 1 - (SSE √∑ SSTO) = (Multiple R)2 In SLR, R2 equals the square of the Pearson correlation between x and y Multiple R is the correlation between yi and y-hati (always positive) In SLR, Multiple R = | rxy |
Recall Pearson r = .318 (weak to moderate positive) Multiple R = .318 (weak to moderate relationship) R2 = .101, indicating 10.1% of variance in movie rating can be explained by running time.
Recall Pearson r = -. 148 (weak negative) Multiple R = .148 (weak relationship) R2 = .022, indicating only 2.2% of variance in movie rating can be explained by the year a movie was released. Omnibus: Comprising several items "Congress passed an omnibus anticrime package." The omnibus test is used to evaluate the significance of overall regression model. Statistics used to conduct the omnibus test are available in the ANOVA table. Many different (equivalent) ways to represent the omnibus test, but they are asking the same question: Is the regression model good enough to be used to explain/predict DV? Since we are comparing variances (SSR and SSE), the sample statistics is compared to a critical F statistics, given the significance level (usually Œ±=. 05). General idea: Large observed F means much variance in DV can be explained by the model (desired)! H0: Œ≤1 = 0 H1: Œ≤1 ‚â† 0 H0: y-hat = y-bar H1: y-hat = b0 +b1x (DV cannot be predicted by model) H0: œÅ = 0 (œÅ is the population correlation between model and data, estimated by Multiple R) H1: œÅ > 0 H0: œÅ2 = 0 H1: œÅ2 > 0 Compare Fobs to the critical F(1, n -2) Reject H0 if Fobs > F(1, n -2) Alternatively, reject H0 if p < Œ± For APA style writing, make sure you report the F statistic along with both degrees of freedom and the p-value.
SSR = 4.918 SSE = 43.609 Fobs = MSR / MSE = (SSR / 1) / (SSE / n - 2) = (4.918 / 1) / (43.609 / 98) = 11.052 Since p = .001, reject H0 (significant model/predictor) Report F (1, 98) = 11.052, p = .001 Can also check R2 = (SSR) / (SSTO) = 4.918 / 48.528 = .101
SSR = 1.057 SSE = 47.471 Fobs = MSR / MSE = (SSR / 1) / (SSE / n - 2) = (1.057 / 1) / (47.471 / 98) = 2.182 Since p = .143, cannot reject H0 (model/predictor not significant) Report F (1, 98) = 2.182, p = .143 Can also check R2 = (SSR) / (SSTO) = 1.057 / 48.528 = .022

item.title: Ratio Variable
item.description: Ratio variables are interval variables, but with the added condition that 0 of the measurement indicates that there is none of that variable. (Continuous Variable are further categorized as either Interval Variable or Ratio Variable) Example: Temperature measured in degrees Celsius or Fahrenheit is not a ratio variable because 0 degrees Celsius does not mean there is no temperature. However, temperature measured in Kelvin is a ratio variable as 0 Kelvin (often called absolute zero) indicates that there is no temperature whatsoever. Other examples of ratio variables include height, mass, distance, etc. The name 'ratio' reflects the fact that you can use the ratio of measurements. So, for example, a distance of ten meters is twice the distance of 5 meters.

item.title: Paired T-Test
item.description: AKA dependent t-test: Dependent variable (DV): Scores being compared Measured on at least an interval level scale Often used to compare post-score to pre-score Independent variable (IV): The treatment or intervention Typical research question: Is there a mean difference between the post-score and pre-score? Also used to compare twins, couples, eyeballs, etc. 20 weeks of cognitive behavioral therapy -> Amount and severity of depressive symptoms Intervention -> Students' math proficiency Constraint induced movement therapy -> hand function One-group pretest-posttest design: O1 (pre) X O2 (post) One-group pretest-posttest design using a double pretest: O1 O2 X O3 One-group pretest-posttest design using a nonequivalent dependent variable: (O1 A, O1 B) x (O2 B, O2 B) The removed-treatment design: O1 x O2 (O3) x O4 The repeated-treatment design: O1 x O2 x O3 x O4 Untreated control group design with dependent pretest and posttest samples NR (Not Random) O1 X O2 NR (Not Random) O1 O2 Untreated control group design with dependent pretest and posttest samples using a double pretest NR O1 O2 X O3 NR O1 O2 O3 Untreated control group design with dependent pretest and posttest samples using switching replications NR O1 x O2 (O3) x O4 NR O1 O2 (O3) x O4 Untreated control group design dependent pretest and posttest samples using reversed-treatment control group NR O1 (pre) X O2 (post) NR O1 (pre) X O2 (post) Nondirectional: Test if post-score (¬µ2) is significantly different from pre-score (¬µ1) H0: ¬µ2 = ¬µ1 vs. H1: ¬µ2 ‚â† ¬µ1 Alternatively, in terms of mean difference: H0: ¬µ2 - ¬µ1 ‚â§ 0 vs. H1: ¬µ2 - ¬µ1 > 0 The mean difference is the difference in pre- and post-scores, so a paired-sample t-test is identical to a one-sample t-test, testing the difference in scores against the hypothesized (test) value! Directional: Test if post-score (¬µ2) is significantly greater from pre-score (¬µ1). H0: ¬µ2 - ¬µ1 ‚â§ 0 vs. H1: ¬µ2 - ¬µ1 > 0 Directional: Test if post-score (¬µ2) is significantly smaller than pre-scores (¬µ1): H0: ¬µ2 - ¬µ1 ‚â• 0 vs. H1: ¬µ2 - ¬µ1 < 0 One Sample StatisticsOne-Sample Test For negative emotion change (hypothesized to decrease), the one-sample t-test is significant, t (33) = -2.393, p = .011. The mean difference is -0.20 (negative emotion decreased after watching the video). The 95% upper confidence limit -. 0585 below zero also provides evidence that the test is significant (change significantly smaller than 0). For positive emotion change (hypothesized to increase), the one-sample t-test is significant, t (33) = 6.448, p < .001. The mean difference is 1.06 (positive emotion increased after watching the video). The 95% lower confidence limit .7809 above zero also provides evidence that the test is significant (change significantly greater than 0). tobs = d √∑ sd-bar or d √∑ (sd √∑ ‚àön) d is the mean difference and sd-bar is the standard error of the mean difference: sd-bar = sd √∑ ‚àön sd is the standard deviation of the difference scores (i.e., like any other standard deviation only this one is computed from the difference scores rather than raw scores). n is the total number of pairs. Recall in one-sample t-test: tobs = ( - ¬µ0) (s √∑ ‚àön) Where is ¬µ0? Given ùõº level, nondirectional or directional, and degree of freedom (df = n - 1), critical t can be found on the t-table (if df is available). Recall rejection region is outside of critical t('s) toward the tail (s). Reject H0 if a positive tobs > tcrit (for negative values: tobs < tcrit) or p < ùõº (SPSS) ùõº level is usually .05 (95% confidence level) Nondirectional: 100 (1 - ùõº)% CI: ¬± tdf, ùõº/2 x sd-bar ¬± tdf, ùõº/2 x (sd-bar √∑ ‚àön) To test greater (significant increase in post-scores): 100 (1 - ùõº)% LCL: - tdf, ùõº/2 x sd-bar To test smaller (significant decrease in post-scores): 100 (1 - ùõº)% UCL: + tdf, ùõº/2 x sd-bar DV data recorded as 2 variables (e.g., pre-score and post-score) in SPSS IV (treatment, intervention) is usually not recorded as a variable in SPSS Analyze -> Compare Means -> Paired-Samples t-test Move the two variables of interest (e.g., pre-score and post-score) to the paired variable 1 and variable 2. Notice the mean difference SPSS computes is variable 1 minus variable 2, so sometimes the sign of observed t can be confusing. However, you can easily figure out if the effect is positive or negative based on the descriptive statistics. I like to enter post-score as variable 1 and pre-score as variable 2 so I can see the change (positive or negative) from pre-score to post-score. Paired Samples StatisticsPaired Samples CorrelationsPaired Samples Test For negative emotion change: sd-bar = sd √∑ ‚àön = .48742 √∑ ‚àö34 = .08359 tobs = d-bar √∑ sd = - .2000 √∑ .08359 = -2.393 For positive emotion change: sd-bar = sd √∑ ‚àön = .95754 √∑ ‚àö34 = .16422 tobs = d-bar √∑ sd = 1.05882 √∑ .16422 = 6.448 Mean difference from pre- to post-score is hypothesized to decrease (one-tailed test). H0: ¬µ2 - ¬µ1 ‚â• 0 vs. H1: ¬µ2 - ¬µ1 < 0 Mean difference d-bar = - .2000, SD sd = .48742, sd-bar = .08359 tobs = -2.393, df = 33, p = .011 Since the p-value (. 011) is smaller than the ùõº level (. 05), we can reject the H0 and conclude that participants' negative emotion significantly decreased after watching the cat videos. Mean difference from pre- to post-score is hypothesized to increase (one-tailed test). H0: ¬µ2 - ¬µ1 ‚â§ 0 vs. H1: ¬µ2 - ¬µ1 > 0 Mean difference d-bar = 1.05882, SD sd = .95754, sd-bar = .16422 tobs = 6.448, df = 33, p < .001 Since the p-value is very small (< .001), we can reject the H0 and conclude that participants' positive emotion significantly increased after watching the cat videos. Cohen's d = d-bar √∑ sd-bar Recall Cohen's d for one-sample t-test: d = ( - ¬µ0) √∑ s Size of Cohen's d (by convention): d = ¬±0.2: Small effect d = ¬±0.5: Medium effect d = ¬±0.8: Large effect Paired Samples Effect Sizes For negative emotion change, Cohen's d (- 0.410) suggests a small to medium effect. For positive emotion change, the effect size (d = 1.106) is quite large. The pre-video and post-video negative emotion scores were collected from a sample of 34 participants, with a pre-score of 4.80 (SD = 0.926) and a post-score mean of 4.60 (SD = 1.028). Thus, negative emotion changed by -0.20 (decrease) after the video. The paired-sample t-test was conducted to determine if this change was significantly smaller than zero (significant decrease after the video), and the results indicate that the post-score was significantly lower than the pre-score, t(33) = -2.393, p = 0.011. The null hypothesis was rejected at the .05 level of significance. The effect size Cohen's d was -0.410. Using Cohen's (1988) guidelines, this is interpreted as a small to medium effect. The results provide evidence to support the conclusion that the negative emotion significantly decreased after watching cat videos. The effect size suggests about 0.4 standard deviation unit difference between pre-score and post-score. The pre-video and post-video positive emotion scores were collected from a sample of 34 participants, with a pre-score of 3.76 (SD = 0.998) and a post-score mean of 4.82 (SD = 1.014). Thus, positive emotion increased by 1.06 after the video. The paired-sample t-test was conducted to determine if this change was significantly greater than zero (significant increase after the video), and the results indicate that the post-score was significantly higher than the pre-score, t(33) = 6.448, p < .001. The null hypothesis was rejected at the .05 level of significance. The effect size Cohen's d was 1.106. Using Cohen's (1988) guidelines, this is interpreted as a large effect. The results provide evidence to support the conclusion that the positive emotion significantly increased after watching cat videos. The effect size suggests more than one standard deviation unit difference between pre-score and post-score. The results from the pre-test (M = 13.5, SD = 2.4) and post-test (M = 16.2, SD = 2.7) memory task indicate that the presence of caffeine in the bloodstream resulted in an improvement in memory recall, t(19) = 3.1, p = .006. There was a significant increase in the volume of alcohol consumed in the week after the end of semester (M = 8.7, SD = 3.1) compared to the week before the end of semester (M = 3.2, SD = 1.5), t(52) = 4.8, p < .001 How to Report the Result of a T-Test (APA style) If you're hypothesis testing, restate your hypothesis. If your t-test is one-tailed, you need to say so. It's preferred to report the exact p-value unless it's smaller than .001. You need to state your alpha level (usually .05) early in the results section. If your p-value is smaller than .001, it's conventional simply to state p < .001 (NEVER report p = 0) Remember to drop the leading 0 from the p-value. No need to provide a formula for observed t in your paper. Observations are from a random sample, and the scores are independent of each other. Dependent variable of interest is measured on at least an interval scale. Difference scores (d's) are normally distributed. Typically considered robust to violations of non-normality, especially for big sample (n > 30) If one of the samples is highly skewed (particularly for a one-tailed test), a lot of error will tend to be built into the difference scores. Other non-parametric analyses would be better alternatives.

item.title: One-Way Independent ANOVA
item.description:
Analysis of Variance (ANOVA)
Dependent Variable (Y; continuous)
Independent Variable (X; categorical, grouping variable) It is equivalent to a t-test but can have more levels (groups tested at once). Used to compare means of two or more independent groups to determine if there is a statistically significant difference between them. Testing whether different teaching methods (Group A, B, C) produce different average exam scores. State the null and alternative hypotheses: H0: ¬µ1 = ¬µ2 ... (¬µ represents the population mean for each group) H1: ¬µ1 ‚â† ¬µ2 ... (at least one mean is different)
Click Analyze > Descriptive Statistics > Explore > Tests for Normality (Shapiro-Wilk Test, Q-Q Plot, Histogram) Go to Analyze > General Linear Model > Univariate
Move your Dependent Variable (e.g., exam scores) to the Dependent Variable box.
Move your Independent Variable (grouping variable) (e.g., teaching method) to the Fixed Factor(s) box. Click Options, check Descriptive Statistics and Homogeneity Tests. Click Continue. Click OK for output and Paste for syntax editor. Interpretation: Since p = 0.12 (p > 0.05), the assumption of equal variances is met. Interpretation: The significant F (F (2, 57) = 5.43, p = 0.008) indicates that at least one group mean is significantly different. "A one-way ANOVA was conducted to examine the effect of teaching method on exam scores. Results indicated a statistically significant difference among the groups, F (2, 57) = 5.43, p = 0.008. Levene's test confirmed the assumption of homogeneity of variances, p = 0.12. Post hoc comparisons using Tukey's HSD indicated that Group A scored significantly higher than Group C (p < 0.05)." Compute SST SSE = ‚àë (Yi - Y-hati)2
Compute the Degrees of Freedom Degrees of Freedom Between Groups dfBG = k - 1 (k is the number of levels / groups / conditions) (between groups) Degrees of Freedom Within Groups (Error) dfE = N - k (N is the total number of participants in a study) (within group / error) Sums of Degrees of Freedom dfTot = N - 1 Compute F Ratio
Variance between groups (proportion of variability in Y explained by X) Variance within groups (proportion of variability in Y unexplained by X) MSBG (Mean square, instead of getting the sum of squares of error, we will be getting the mean square; BG: between group; E: error or within group)
Values for the F statistic should all be positive. F = 1 means no mean difference because the between and within group variabilities would be the same. The higher your F, the greater change of it being significant (would mean there is a much higher variability between groups than you see within groups) Complete F Table Compare the calculated F-value against the F-crit value If F-value is greater than F-crit then you can say there is a statistically significant difference between the means of the groups. When looking at the F-crit table, the df between is horizontal and df within is vertical. Make a Decision Write up the F-values (i.e., F (1,10) = 41.227, p < .001). A bar graph can be used to visually depict the differences as well. Example Language: "We conducted a one-way analysis of variance (ANOVA) to examine whether there was a mean difference of depression scores between subjects who were diagnosed with depression and who were not. The ANOVA results showed that there was a statistically significant mean difference between the two groups (F (1,22) = 117.42, p < .001)." The one-way analysis of variance (ANOVA) is used to determine whether there are any statistically significant differences between the means of three or more independent (unrelated) groups. The one-way ANOVA compares the means between the groups you are interested in and determines whether any of those means are statistically significantly different from each other. Specifically, it tests the null hypothesis:
Where ¬µ = group mean and k = number of groups. If, however, the one-way ANOVA returns a statistically significant result, we accept the alternative hypothesis, which is that there are at least two group means that are statistically significantly different from each other. The one-way ANOVA is an Omnibus test statistic, and cannot tell you which specific groups were statistically significantly different from each other, only that at least two groups were. To determine which specific groups differed from each other, you need to use a post hoc test. It is used to test research questions and hypotheses where you want to compare the means of three or more groups on a single dependent variable. You are asking if there is a significant difference between the groups based on a single categorical independent variable with multiple levels. If you are dealing with individuals, you are likely to encounter this situation using two different types of study design: One study design is to recruit a group of individuals and then randomly split this group into three or more smaller groups (i.e., each participant is allocated to one, and only one, group). You then get each group to undertake different tests (or put them under different conditions) and measure the outcome/response on the same dependent variable. For example, a researcher wishes to know whether different pacing strategies affect the time to complete a marathon. The researcher randomly assigns a group of volunteers to either a group that (a) starts slow and then increases their speed, (b) starts fast and slows down or (c) runs at a steady pace throughout. The time to complete the marathon is the outcome (dependent) variable.
A second study design is to recruit a group of individuals and then split them into groups based on some independent variable. Again, each individual will be assigned to one group only. This independent variable is sometimes called an attribute independent variable because you are splitting the group based on some attribute that they possess (e.g., their level of education; every individual has a level of education, even if it is 'none'). Each group is then measured on the same dependent variable having undergone the same task or condition (or none at all). For example, a researcher is interested in determining whether there are differences in leg strength between amateur, semi-professional and provessional rugby players. The force/strength measured on an isokinetic machine is the dependent variable.

Every time you conduct a t-test there is a chance that you will make a Type I Errors. This error is usually 5%. By running two t-tests on the same data you will have increased your chance of "making a mistake" to 10%. The formula for determining the new error rate for multiple t-tests is not as simple as multiplying 5% by the number of tests. However, if you are only making a few multiple comparisons, the results are very similar if you do. As such, three t-tests would be 15% (actually, 14.3%) and so on. These are unacceptable errors. An ANOVA controls for these errors so that the Type I Errors remains at 5% and you can be more confident that any statistically significant result you find is not just running lots of tests. When you choose to analyze your data using a one-way ANOVA, part of the process involves checking to make sure that the data you want to analyze can actually be analyzed using a one-way ANOVA. You need to do this because it is only appropriate to use a one-way ANOVA if your data "passes" six assumptions that are required for a one-way ANOVA to give you a valid result.
Your dependent variable should be measured at the interval or ratio level (Interval Variable and Ratio Variable) (i.e., they are Continuous Variable; IQ score, exam scores, weight, etc). The dependent variable is normally distributed in each group that is being compared in the one-way ANOVA (technically, it is the residuals that need to be normally distributed, but the results will be the same).
For example, if we were comparing three groups (e.g., amateur, semi-professional, and professional rugby players) on their leg strength, their leg strength values (Dependent Variable) would have to be normally distributed for the amateur group of players, normally distributed for the semi-professionals and normally distributed for the professional player. You can test for normality in SPSS.
Testing for Normality There is homogeneity of variances. This means that the population variances in each group are equal. If you use SPSS Statistics, Levene's Test for Homogeneity of Variances is included in the output when you run a one-way ANOVA in SPSS Statistics.
Independence of Observations. This is mostly a study design issue and, as such, you will need to determine whether you believe it is possible that your observations are not independent based on your study design.
Your Independent Variable should consist of two or more categorical, independent groups. Typically, a one-way ANOVA is used when you have three or more categorical, independent groups, but it can be used for just two groups (but an Independent Samples T-Test Independent Samples T-Test is more commonly used for two groups) Example independent variables that meet this criterion include ethnicity (e.g., 3 groups: Caucasian, African American, and Hispanic), physical activity level (e.g., 4 groups: sedentary, low, moderate, and high), profession (e.g., 5 groups: surgeon, doctor, nurse, dentist, therapist) and so forth.
You should have Independence of Observations, which means that there is no relationship between the observations in each group or between the groups themselves. For example, there must be different participants in each group with no participant being in more than one group. This is more of a study design issue than something you can test for. If your study fails this assumption, you will need to use another statistical test instead of the one-way ANOVA (e.g., a repeated measures design). There should be no significant outliers. Outliers are simply data points within your data that do not follow the usual pattern (e.g., in a study of 100 students' IQ scores, where the mean score was 108 with only a small variation between students, one student had a score of 156, which is very unusual, and may even put her in the top 1% of IQ scores globally). The problem with outliers is that they can have a negative effect on the one-way ANOVA, reducing the validity of your results.
Your Dependent Variable should be approximately normally distributed for each category of the Independent Variable. We talk about the one-way ANOVA only requiring approximately normal data because it is quite 'robust' to violations of normality, meaning that assumption can be a little violated and still provide valid results. You can test for normality using the Shapiro-Wilk test of normality, which is easily tested for using SPSS Statistics.
There needs to be Homogeneity of Variances. You can test this assumption in SPSS Statistics using Levene's test for homogeneity of variances. If your data fails this assumption, you will need to not only carry out a Welch ANOVA instead of a one-way ANOVA, which you can do using SPSS Statistics, but also use a different post hoc test.
The one-way ANOVA is considered a robust test against the normality assumption. This means that it tolerates violations to its normality assumption rather well. As regards the normality of group data, the one-way ANOVA can tolerate data that is non-normal (skewed or kurtotic distributions) with only a small effect on the Type I Errors rate. However, platykurtosis can have a profound effect when your group sizes are small. This leaves you with two options: Transform your data using various algorithms so that the shape of your distributions become normally distributed Choose the nonparametric Kruskal-Wallis H Test which does not require the assumption of normality. There are two tests that you can run that are applicable when the assumption of homogeneity of variances has been violated. Welch Brown and Forsythe test. Alternatively, you can run a Kruskal-Wallis H Test. For most situations, it has been shown that the Welch test is the best. Both the Welch and Brown and Forsythe tests are available in SPSS. A lack of independence of cases has been stated as the most serious assumptions to fail. Often, there is little you can do that offers a good solution to this problem. Analyze -> Compare Means -> One-Way ANOVA

Add Dependent Variable to the Dependent List box, and add the Independent Variable to the Factor box. Click Options. Check the box for Means Plot, then click Continue. Click OK when finished. ONEWAY Sprint BY Smoking /PLOT MEANS /MISSING ANALYSIS.
The Dependent Variable. This is the variable whose means will be compared between the samples (groups). You may run multiple means comparisons simultaneously by selecting more than one dependent variable.
The Independent Variable. The categories (or groups) of the independent variable will define which samples will be compared. The independent variable must have at least two categories (groups), but usually has three or more groups when used in a One-Way ANOVA. Specify contrasts, or planned comparisons, to be conducted after the overall ANOVA test. When the initial F-test indicates that significant differences exist between group means, contrasts are useful for determining which specific means are significantly different when you have specific hypotheses that you wish to test. Contrasts are decided before analyzing the data (i.e., priori). Contrasts break down the variance into component parts. They may involve using weights, non-orthogonal comparisons, standard contrasts, and polynomial contrasts (trend analysis).
Request post hoc (also known as multiple comparisons) tests. Specific post hoc tests can be selected by checking the associated boxes.
When the initial F test indicates that significant differences exist between group means, post hoc tests are useful for determining which specific means are significantly different when you do not have specific hypotheses you wish to test. Post hoc tests compare each pair of means (like T-Test s), but unlike T-Test s, they correct the significance estimate to account for the multiple comparisons.
Multiple comparisons options that assume homogeneity of variance (each group has equal variance). By default, a 2-sided hypothesis test is selected. Alternatively, a directional, one-sided hypothesis can be specified if you choose to use a Dunnett post hoc test. Click the box next to Dunnett and then specify whether the Control Category is the Last or First group, numerically, of your grouping variable. In the Test area, click either < Control or > Control. The one-tailed options require that you specify whether you predict that the mean for the specified control group will be less than (> Control) or greater than (< Control) another group. Multiple comparisons options that do not assume equal variances. The desired cutoff for statistical significance. By default, significance is set to 0.05. Clicking Options will produce a window where you can specify which Statistics to include in the output (Descriptive, Fixed and Random Effects, Homogeneity of Variance Test, Brown-Forsythe, Welch), whether to include a Means Plot, and how the analysis will address Missing Values (i.e., Exclude cases analysis by analysis or Exclude cases listwise). Click Continue when you are finished making specifications.
You will have calculated the following results or obtained them from SPSS.
"There was a statistically significant difference between groups as determined by one-way ANOVA (F (2, 27) = 4.467, p = .021)." this is all you will need to write for the one-way ANOVA per se. However, you will probably also want to report means ¬± Standard Deviation (SD) s for your groups, as well as follow up a statistically significant result with a post hoc test. The general form of writing the result of a one-way ANOVA is as follow:
You should not report the result as 'Significant difference,' but instead report it as 'statistically significant difference.' this is because your devision as to whether the result is significant or not should not be based solely on your statistical test. Report the result of the one-way ANOVA (e.g., 'There were no statistically significant differences between group means as determined by one-way ANOVA (F (2, 27) = 1.397, p = .15)'). Running a post hoc test is usually not warranted and should not be carried out. You need to report your results. You then need to follow-up the one-way ANOVA by running a post hoc test. You need to perform the same procedures as above, but add into your results section that this assumption was violated and you needed to run a Welch F test. ANOVA test tells you whether you have an overall difference between your groups, but it does not tell you which specific groups differed - post hoc tests do. Because post hoc tests are run to confirm where the differences occurred between groups, they should only be run when you have a shown an overall statistically significant difference in group means (i.e., a statistically significant one-way ANOVA result). Post hoc tests attempt to control the experiment-wise error rate (usually alpha = 0.05) in the same manner that the one-way ANOVA is used instead of multiple t-tests. Post hoc tests are termed a posteriori tests; that is, performed after the event (the event in this case being a study). There are a great number of different post hoc tests that you can use. However, you should only run one post hoc test - do not run multiple post hoc tests. For a one-way ANOVA, you will probably find that just two tests need to be considered. If your data met the assumption of homogeneity of variances, use Tukey's honestly significant difference (HSD) post hoc test. Note that if you use SPSS Statistics, Tukey's HSD test is simply referred to as 'Tukey' in the post post hoc multiple comparisons dialogue box. If your data did not meet the homogeneity fo variances assumption, you should consider running the Games Howell post hoc test.
